Description: Jar stopper; plaster; whitish colour. Top is decorated with an impressed design of a central cross around which is a Latin inscription preceded by a cross. The latin text reads Spes in Deo (Hope in God, or in God we trust). Impression of organic material left by missing plug on the underside. Mark left by pull string on the side.
Curator's comments: Plaster stoppers of this type , were commonly used on wine-amphorae (Thomas 2011, type 1; Thomas and Tomber 2006, type 1) . This method of sealing wine-amphorae with plaster stoppers was common in Egypt and North Africa during the Roman and Byzantine periods (Thomas 2011, type 7; Thomas and Tomber 2006, type 7). Unlike the mud stoppers (e.g., EA 53951–54) that were used on wine-amphorae produced by estates, this type of plaster stopper (e.g., EA 53955, 53957–63) was commonly used on wine-amphorae used by wine traders (Thomas 2011, type 7; Thomas and Tomber 2006: type7). Cf., stoppers from late Roman contexts at Kellia (Egloff 1977, pl. 20.3–6) and Clysma (Bruyère 1966, fig. 10). For the cross stamp, cf., impressions from Western Thebes (Winlock and Crum, 80, fig. 33.1–2). The motif is common on Late Roman amphora stoppers in Egypt, e.g., at Kellia (Egloff 1977, pl. 20.3–7) and Clysma (Bruyère 1966, fig. 10). For the stamp itself, cf. a similar, simple circular cross on a wooden stamp without text found at Koptos (Nachtergael 2000, 289, fig. 23). See also EA 53951. Bruyère, B. 1966.
